elements.content: The assemblies of a p-conjugated organic luminophore ligand (p-tr2Ph) and d10 transition metal cations produce two metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn­(μ4-p-tr2Ph)­(μ2-NO3)]·NO3 (1), and {[Cd2(μ4-1,4-BDC)2­(μ4-p-tr2Ph)­(μ2 -DMF)­(H2O)2]}­·2H2O (2) (p-tr2Ph = 1,4-phenylene-4,4′-bis­(1,2,4-triazole), DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, 1,4-H2BDC = 1,4-dicarboxybenzene). Compound 1 is a new three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework with left-handed helical channels constructed from a right-handed helical chain [Zn­(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n . Compound 2 possesses a 3D 3-fold interpenetrated neutral framework with one-dimensional distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. The compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit blue fluorescence. Notably, the intensity-based luminescent thermometer measurements reveal that compound 2 is extremely more linear with temperature, has finer reversibility within three cycles, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1, indicating that compound 2 is a more desirable low-temperature detector.

Compound 1 is a new three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework with left-handed helical channels constructed from a right-handed helical chain [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n . Compound 2 possesses a 3D 3-fold interpenetrated neutral framework with one-dimensional distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. The compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit blue fluorescence. Notably, the intensity-based luminescent thermometer measurements reveal that compound 2 is extremely more linear with temperature, has finer reversibility within three cycles, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1, indicating that compound 2 is a more desirable low-temperature detector.

elements.content: Two intensity-based luminescent metal−organic frameworks thermometers were self-assembled by d10 metal cations and a p-conjugated lumophore ligand. Compound 1 is a rare chiral three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework containing a one-dimensional right-handed helical column and left-handed helical channels. Compound 2 is a three-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with an interesting MIL-88 type single-net. Notably, compound 2 shows more linearity, finer reversibility, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: Two intensity-based luminescent metal-organic frameworks thermometers were self-assembled by d10 metal cations and a p-conjugated lumophore ligand. Compound 1 is a rare chiral three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework containing a one-dimensional right-handed helical column and left-handed helical channels. Compound 2 is a three-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with an interesting MIL-88 type single-net. Notably, compound 2 shows more linearity, finer reversibility, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

The luminescent thermometry techniques, especially luminescent ultralow temperature detection, play vital roles in the superconductivity, medical science, energy industry fields, and so on. Luminescent molecular thermometers provide a promising alternative in temperature detection because of their observability, accuracy, quick response, detection convenience, high resolution, high sensitivity, and universality even under strong electric or magnetic fields and changing environment. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), built up from all kinds of inorganic metal cations and/or clusters nodes with various organic ligands linkers, turn out to be a rational candidate for luminescent molecular thermometers owing to the abundance of metal cations and the luxuriance of organic connectors with diverse geometries and lumophore functional groups. A considerable number of luminescent MOF thermometer compounds have been designed for temperature-dependent fluorescence, for example, peak position, emission intensity, and fluorescence lifetime. However, only a few luminescent MOF thermometer materials have been studied for quantitative detection.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

The luminescent thermometry techniques, especially luminescent ultralow temperature detection, play vital roles in the superconductivity, medical science, energy industry fields, and so on. Luminescent molecular thermometers provide a promising alternative in temperature detection because of their observability, accuracy, quick response, detection convenience, high resolution, high sensitivity, and universality even under strong electric or magnetic fields and changing environment. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), built up from all kinds of inorganic metal cations and/or clusters nodes with various organic ligands linkers, turn out to be a rational candidate for luminescent molecular thermometers owing to the abundance of metal cations and the luxuriance of organic connectors with diverse geometries and lumophore functional groups. A considerable number of luminescent MOF thermometer compounds have been designed for temperature-dependent fluorescence, for example, peak position, emission intensity, and fluorescence lifetime. However, only a few luminescent MOF thermometer materials have been studied for quantitative detection.

elements.content: Up to now, some ratiometric luminescent MOFs thermometers based upon lanthanide complexes were prepared. In contrast with lanthanide complexes, fluorescent transition-metal compounds often have a single emission peak, ultraviolet–visible-range absorption, medium brightness, and wide Stokes shifts. These characteristics of the fluorescent transition-metal compounds are advantageous for luminescent molecular thermometers, but only a few well researched transition metal complexes have been utilized as intensity-based luminescent molecular thermometers. The transition metal complexes as luminescent molecular thermometers are focused on the metal complexes with d10 configuration, which could be good structural units and could take part in the luminescence of materials. Their luminescent properties can be modulated by organic ligands, guest molecules, and intrinsic three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. These intriguing luminescent properties at low temperatures allow us to explore and design low-temperature luminescent MOF thermometers.

In contrast with lanthanide complexes, fluorescent transition-metal compounds often have a single emission peak, ultraviolet-visible-range absorption, medium brightness, and wide Stokes shifts. These characteristics of the fluorescent transition-metal compounds are advantageous for luminescent molecular thermometers, but only a few well researched transition metal complexes have been utilized as intensity-based luminescent molecular thermometers. The transition metal complexes as luminescent molecular thermometers are focused on the metal complexes with d10 configuration, which could be good structural units and could take part in the luminescence of materials. Their luminescent properties can be modulated by organic ligands, guest molecules, and intrinsic three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. These intriguing luminescent properties at low temperatures allow us to explore and design low-temperature luminescent MOF thermometers.

elements.content: Due to its unique coordination abilities and organic lumophore unit, the p-conjugated p-tr2Ph ligand, with three N atoms as electron donors in each triazole ring, has currently aroused great attraction in the coordination polymer field. In the assembly process of MOFs, the p-tr2Ph ligand can act as a multidentate or a bridge linker to connect metal centers. However, the poor water-solubility of p-tr2Ph ligand makes it difficult to link with metal ions, and to date, few p-tr2Ph-based MOFs have been documented. What is more, MOFs constructed from mixed ligands of p-tr2Ph and other aromatic carboxylic ligands reported in references are very limited. In order to further enrich the coordination assembly of the p-tr2Ph linker, we chose a very versatile organic ligand 1,4-H2BDC as an ancillary linker because it is not only easy to coordinate with most metal ions in the Periodic Table of Elements, but also it matches the relative metrics (length and linking mode) of the p-tr2Ph ligand as a linear connector. Moreover, the construction of MOFs from multiple components based on mixed-linkers is a pathway to design materials with high tunability and functionality.

In the assembly process of MOFs, the p-tr2Ph ligand can act as a multidentate or a bridge linker to connect metal centers. However, the poor water-solubility of p-tr2Ph ligand makes it difficult to link with metal ions, and to date, few p-tr2Ph-based MOFs have been documented. What is more, MOFs constructed from mixed ligands of p-tr2Ph and other aromatic carboxylic ligands reported in references are very limited. In order to further enrich the coordination assembly of the p-tr2Ph linker, we chose a very versatile organic ligand 1,4-H2BDC as an ancillary linker because it is not only easy to coordinate with most metal ions in the Periodic Table of Elements, but also it matches the relative metrics (length and linking mode) of the p-tr2Ph ligand as a linear connector. Moreover, the construction of MOFs from multiple components based on mixed-linkers is a pathway to design materials with high tunability and functionality.

elements.content: Herein, we present two luminescent MOFs, [Zn­(μ4-p-tr2Ph)­(μ2-NO3)]·NO3 (1) and {[Cd2(μ4-1,4-BDC)2­(μ4-p-tr2Ph)­(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]}­·2H2O (2), as low-temperature intensity-based luminescent molecular thermometers, which are constructed from d10 transition metals as metal nodes and two organic lumophores, 1,4-H2BDC and p-tr2Ph as the bridging linkers. Compound 1 is a new 3D chiral MOF based on [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)] n helical chains with right-handedness running along the c-axis with triangular left-handed helical channels. However, compound 1 is optically inactive, and this maybe because the bulk sample is racemate. Compound 2 possesses a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral framework with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. Their thermosensitive emission spectra arise from the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of p-tr2Ph ligand. Though the structure of compound 2 has been reported, its temperature-dependent luminescent property has never been documented. The low variable-temperature fluorescence experiment reveals compound 2 is a preferable candidate for low temperature detection with much more linear correlation, finer reversibility, and wider temperature range than those of compound 1.

Compound 1 is a new 3D chiral MOF based on [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n  helical chains with right-handedness running along the c-axis with triangular left-handed helical channels. However, compound 1 is optically inactive, and this maybe because the bulk sample is racemate. Compound 2 possesses a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral framework with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. Their thermosensitive emission spectra arise from the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of p-tr2Ph ligand. Though the structure of compound 2 has been reported, its temperature-dependent luminescent property has never been documented. The low variable-temperature fluorescence experiment reveals compound 2 is a preferable candidate for low temperature detection with much more linear correlation, finer reversibility, and wider temperature range than those of compound 1.

elements.content:
All the chemicals commercial available were used directly. The p-tr2Ph was prepared by the literature method.

Synthesis of [Zn­(μ<sub>4</sub>-<italic>p</italic>-tr<sub>2</sub>Ph)­(μ<sub>2</sub>-NO<sub>3</sub>)]·NO<sub>3</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The mixture of p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60.2 mg), 1 mL of DMF, and 5 mL of CH3CN solvents was added to a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred for about 1 h, the resulting mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and was kept at 85 °C for 5 days. After being naturally cooled to ambient temperature, the colorless columnar crystals of 1 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 86% (based on p-tr2Ph). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C10H8N8O6Zn: N, 27.90; H, 2.01; C, 29.90. Found: N, 27.56; H, 2.12; C, 29.76. IR (solid ATR, cm–1): 3367­(w), 3263­(m), 1647(s), 1563(s), 1373(s), 1237­(w), 1102­(w), 1054­(w), 1017­(w), 887­(w), 834­(w), 759­(m), 647­(w).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Synthesis Methods

All the chemicals commercial available were used directly. The p-tr2Ph was prepared by the literature method. 

Synthesis of [Zn(μ4-p-tr2Ph)(μ2-NO3)]⋅NO3 (1)

The mixture of p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60.2 mg), 1 mL of DMF, and 5 mL of CH3CN solvents was added to a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred for about 1 h, the resulting mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and was kept at 85 °C for 5 days. After being naturally cooled to ambient temperature, the colorless columnar crystals of 1 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 86% (based on p-tr2Ph). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C10H8N8O6Zn: N, 27.90; H, 2.01; C, 29.90. Found: N, 27.56; H, 2.12; C, 29.76. IR (solid ATR, cm-1): 3367(w), 3263(m), 1647(s), 1563(s), 1373(s), 1237(w), 1102(w), 1054(w), 1017(w), 887(w), 834(w), 759(m), 647(w).

elements.content: CdSO4 (42.4 mg), p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), and 1,4-H2BDC (17.6 mg), 1 mL of DMF, 3 mL of CH3CN, and 2 mL of H2O were added into a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred at for about 1 h, the mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and then was kept at 100 °C for 5 days. After being cooled to ambient temperature, white columnar crystals of 2 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 78% (based on p-tr2Ph). This synthetic method is different from that in the literature and has the advantage of high yields.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cd2(μ4-1,4-BDC)2(μ4-p-tr2Ph)(μ2-DMF)(H2O)2]}⋅2H2O (2)

CdSO4 (42.4 mg), p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), and 1,4-H2BDC (17.6 mg), 1 mL of DMF, 3 mL of CH3CN, and 2 mL of H2O were added into a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred at for about 1 h, the mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and then was kept at 100 °C for 5 days. After being cooled to ambient temperature, white columnar crystals of 2 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 78% (based on p-tr2Ph). This synthetic method is different from that in the literature and has the advantage of high yields.

elements.content: The poor water-dissolvability of the p-tr2Ph ligand is a great challenge for the construction of p-tr2Ph-based MOFs. Furthermore, the flexibility of p-tr2Ph ligand makes it possible to construct MOFs with intriguing structures. To synthesize MOFs based on the p-tr2Ph ligand, several strategies have been employed: (1) The solvothermal synthesis method was used for the preparation of compounds 1 and 2 since this synthesis method not only increases the solubility of the p-tr2Ph ligand and as-synthesized compounds, but also usually favors an ordered molecular self-assembly. (2) The mixed-linkers strategy was employed. In view of the similar coordinated mode, matched topology and length of ligands, the common carboxylic ligand, 1,4-H2BDC, was selected as an auxiliary ligand to construct the mixed-ligands MOFs, such as compound 2. (3) The suitable solvents were explored. Compound 1 yielded in organic mixed-solvents (DMF/CH3CN), which is beneficial to the dissolution of the p-tr2Ph ligand, while compound 2 crystallizes in tricomponent solvents system (DMF/CH3CN/H2O) because of the incorporation of auxiliary ligand. Importantly, the tricomponent solvent system is beneficial to adjust the dissolvability of p-tr2Ph via changing the volume ratio of solvents. In addition, owing to the less moisture absorption and poorer water solubility of cadmium sulfate compared to zinc nitrate hexahydrate, the introduction of additional water into the mixed-solvents is necessary to synthesize compound 2. Furthermore, the volume ratio of the tricomponent solvent system has a significant effect on synthesis of the compound 2. No products of compound 2 were obtained in other volume ratios of the tricomponent solvent system. (4) The reaction temperature is another key factor for the synthesis. In detail, a large proportion of low boiling point solvent CH3CN was inputted, and thus compound 1 can be achieved at low temperature 85 °C, while for compound 2, the higher reaction temperature, 100 °C, is necessary by introducing a considerable amount of water to the system, which has a relatively high boiling point and poor solubility for p-tr2Ph. The previous reported synthesis condition of compound 2 is rather harsher than that of our work. In our work, the expensive and hygroscopic Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O was replaced by cheap and stable CdSO4, and the NaOH solution was unnecessary. At the same time, there is a higher yield of complex 2 by our method than the reported method in the previous references.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The poor water-dissolvability of the p-tr2Ph ligand is a great challenge for the construction of p-tr2Ph-based MOFs. Furthermore, the flexibility of p-tr2Ph ligand makes it possible to construct MOFs with intriguing structures. To synthesize MOFs based on the p-tr2Ph ligand, several strategies have been employed: (1) The solvothermal synthesis method was used for the preparation of compounds 1 and 2 since this synthesis method not only increases the solubility of the p-tr2Ph ligand and as-synthesized compounds, but also usually favors an ordered molecular self-assembly. (2) The mixed-linkers strategy was employed. In view of the similar coordinated mode, matched topology and length of ligands, the common carboxylic ligand, 1,4-H2BDC, was selected as an auxiliary ligand to construct the mixed-ligands MOFs, such as compound 2. (3) The suitable solvents were explored. Compound 1 yielded in organic mixed-solvents (DMF/CH3CN), which is beneficial to the dissolution of the p-tr2Ph ligand, while compound 2 crystallizes in tricomponent solvents system (DMF/CH3CN/H2O) because of the incorporation of auxiliary ligand. Importantly, the tricomponent solvent system is beneficial to adjust the dissolvability of p-tr2Ph via changing the volume ratio of solvents. In addition, owing to the less moisture absorption and poorer water solubility of cadmium sulfate compared to zinc nitrate hexahydrate, the introduction of additional water into the mixed-solvents is necessary to synthesize compound 2. Furthermore, the volume ratio of the tricomponent solvent system has a significant effect on synthesis of the compound 2. No products of compound 2 were obtained in other volume ratios of the tricomponent solvent system. (4) The reaction temperature is another key factor for the synthesis. In detail, a large proportion of low boiling point solvent CH3CN was inputted, and thus compound 1 can be achieved at low temperature 85 °C, while for compound 2, the higher reaction temperature, 100 °C, is necessary by introducing a considerable amount of water to the system, which has a relatively high boiling point and poor solubility for p-tr2Ph. The previous reported synthesis condition of compound 2 is rather harsher than that of our work. In our work, the expensive and hygroscopic Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O was replaced by cheap and stable CdSO4, and the NaOH solution was unnecessary. At the same time, there is a higher yield of complex 2 by our method than the reported method in the previous references.

elements.content: The crystallographic data including the lattice parameters, data collection, and refinements parameters of 1 are summarized in . Compound 1 shows a 3D cationic framework built from a right-handed helical chain [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)] n with left-handed chiral 31 helical channels running along the c axis. The asymmetrical unit includes one-half-occupied Zn­(II) cations, half p-tr2Ph, and half coordinated NO3 – anion (Figure S1a, Supporting Information). The six-coordinated Zn­(II) ion adopts a distorted ZnN4O2 octahedron: four N atoms from four individual p-tr2Ph organic ligands and two O atoms of two distinct NO3 – anions to give a [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)]+ (tr = triazolyl) structural unit (a). The [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)]+ structural units could serve as the repeating fragments and self-assemble into a one-dimensional (1D) right-handed helical column. The helical column is made of four right-handed 61 helical chains running along the c axis, and their pitches are all 19.8206(13) Å. First, Zn atoms aggregate along the c axis with 61 symmetry operation in the innermost core of the 1D right-handed helical column structures. Next, the coordinated NO3 – anions bridged the Zn atoms to form a chiral -Zn-NO3- helical chain. The types of the last two parallel helical chains consist of six repeating -Zn-tr- linkages, respectively (b). The p-tr2Ph ligands link the right-handed helical columns into a 3D cationic framework with triangular chiral 31 helical channels with left-handedness extending along the c axis (c–e), and the side length is about 1.2 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description

Structural Description of Compound 1 

The crystallographic data including the lattice parameters, data collection, and refinements parameters of 1 are summarized in . Compound 1 shows a 3D cationic framework built from a right-handed helical chain [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n  with left-handed chiral 31 helical channels running along the c axis. The asymmetrical unit includes one-half-occupied Zn(II) cations, half p-tr2Ph, and half coordinated NO3 - anion (Figure S1a, Supporting Information). The six-coordinated Zn(II) ion adopts a distorted ZnN4O2 octahedron: four N atoms from four individual p-tr2Ph organic ligands and two O atoms of two distinct NO3 - anions to give a [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)]+ (tr = triazolyl) structural unit (a). The [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)]+ structural units could serve as the repeating fragments and self-assemble into a one-dimensional (1D) right-handed helical column. The helical column is made of four right-handed 61 helical chains running along the c axis, and their pitches are all 19.8206(13) Å. First, Zn atoms aggregate along the c axis with 61 symmetry operation in the innermost core of the 1D right-handed helical column structures. Next, the coordinated NO3 - anions bridged the Zn atoms to form a chiral -Zn-NO3- helical chain. The types of the last two parallel helical chains consist of six repeating -Zn-tr- linkages, respectively (b). The p-tr2Ph ligands link the right-handed helical columns into a 3D cationic framework with triangular chiral 31 helical channels with left-handedness extending along the c axis (c-e), and the side length is about 1.2 nm.

elements.content: Unlike the previously reported paddlewheel substructural chains constructed by the metal ions and azole motifs, M­(bpb), [Mn4(bpt)3­(NO3)2(def)6], [Fe2(H0.67 bpt)3]­·13H2O, {[Cd­(μ2-p-tr2Ph)3]­(X)2} n , [Cu3(μ2-OH)2­(μ3-SO4)2­(μ4-p-tr2Ph)­(H2O)2], [Fe­(Htz)3]­(BF4)2­·H2O, [Cr­(bpt)­(def)]·def, [Fe­(Htz)2(tz)]­(BF4), Co­(bpt)­·2DEF­·H2O, [Cd­(μ2-p-tr2Ph)­(p-tr2Ph)­(H2O)3] n , and [Cd3(μ3-p-tr2Ph)6­(BF4)5(PF6)]­·18H2O (Htz = triazole, bpt = 5,5′-bis (1,4-phenylene)­(1H-tetrazole), DEF = diethylformamide, bpb = 1,4-(4-bispyrazolyl)­benzene, M = Ni, Co, and Zn, X = ClO4 – and BF4 –), the terminal coordinated μ2-NO3 – anions result in the lack of connectivity in the ab plane each 120° interval in the three-paddles paddlewheel substructure of compound 1 (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Similar linkages have been observed in Mn2(bpt)­Cl2(DMF)2­·1.5CH3OH­·H2O, {[Cd­(Hbpt)­Cl]­·3DMF­·4H2O} n , Cu­(bpt)­(DMF)­·CH3OH­·0.25DMF, whose connections were terminated partly by coordinated Cl– or DMF molecules, respectively.

elements.content: In the whole structure, the free NO3 – anions are suspended in the channels for neutralization of the cationic framework, which can be confirmed by element analysis and valence calculation. PLATON calculation shows compound 1 has 50.7% potential guest-accessible volumes (1679.0 Å3) without free NO3 – anions (Figure S3, Supporting Information). From the topological viewpoint, compound 1 exhibits a 3D (4, 6)-network topology. The μ4-p-tr2Ph ligands can be viewed as the 4-connected nodes, and the six-coordinated Zn­(II) cations can be served as 6-connected nodes (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The Schlafli symbol is {32.63.7}­{34.42.63.74.82}, determined by the TOPOS4 program.

elements.content: Though the structure description of compound 2 has been documented, we describe the structure of 2 from another point of view to better understand the structure. Compound 2 possesses a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral framework with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each single-net. As shown in a, the two neighboring CdO4N2 octahedrons are bridged by μ2-DMF molecules to form a vertex-sharing dinuclear six-paddle paddlewheel cadmium cluster [Cd2(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]4+ SBU. The six paddles of the paddlewheel cadmium cluster [Cd2(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]4+ SBU are two tr motifs from two p-tr2Ph ligands and four carboxyl groups from four 1,4-BDC2– ligands. Unlike the right-handed [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)] n 61 helical column in compound 1, five dinuclear [Cd2(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]4+ clusters are supported by four 1,4-BDC2– ligands and two p-tr2Ph ligands to give a trigonal bipyramidal cage (b and Figure S5) in compound 2, and every cage is closely linked by other six trigonal bipyramidal cages by the common faces or the vertexes to produce a 3D MOF with 1D distorted hexagonal channels running along the c axis and the aperture size is approximately 1.9 × 1.6 nm2 (c and Figure S6a).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of Compound 2 

Though the structure description of compound 2 has been documented, we describe the structure of 2 from another point of view to better understand the structure. Compound 2 possesses a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral framework with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each single-net. As shown in a, the two neighboring CdO4N2 octahedrons are bridged by μ2-DMF molecules to form a vertex-sharing dinuclear six-paddle paddlewheel cadmium cluster [Cd2(μ2-DMF)(H2O)2]4+ SBU. The six paddles of the paddlewheel cadmium cluster [Cd2(μ2-DMF)(H2O)2]4+ SBU are two tr motifs from two p-tr2Ph ligands and four carboxyl groups from four 1,4-BDC2- ligands. Unlike the right-handed [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n  61 helical column in compound 1, five dinuclear [Cd2(μ2-DMF)(H2O)2]4+ clusters are supported by four 1,4-BDC2- ligands and two p-tr2Ph ligands to give a trigonal bipyramidal cage (b and Figure S5) in compound 2, and every cage is closely linked by other six trigonal bipyramidal cages by the common faces or the vertexes to produce a 3D MOF with 1D distorted hexagonal channels running along the c axis and the aperture size is approximately 1.9 × 1.6 nm2 (c and Figure S6a).

All H atoms and free water molecules are removed for clarity.

elements.content: Furthermore, the void space in each single-net is large enough to interpenetrate with two other hexagonal networks to form a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D neutral MOF (d and Figure S6b). Calculated by the PLATON software, the total free capacity of compound 2 without the solvent molecules is 11.2%. Topological analysis was performed to understand the framework better. The dinuclear cadmium cluster SBUs served as a 6-connected nodes which are connected with six adjacent SBUs by four 1,4-BDC2– ligands and two p-tr2Ph ligands as bridges. The whole framework of compound 2 is a uninodal 6-c 3-fold interpenetrating nets with a topological point symbol of {49.66} (e and Figure S8).

elements.content: A similar uninodal 6-connected topology is found in the MIL-88 series (Figure S7, Supporting Information). Nevertheless, the 6-connect nodes in MIL-88 series are trimeric metal-oxo clusters with C 3 symmetry. The trimeric metal-oxo clusters are linked by monotonous 2-connect carboxylate ligands, finally leading to a 3D neutral framework. The unique structural features of compound 2 enrich the diversity of these materials in component and structure which provide a good example to investigate the difference among their structures and properties.

elements.content: Comparatively, compound 1 is constructed by transition metal Zn­(II) and single organic ligand p-tr2Ph, and presents right-handed helical columns, triangular chiral right-handed 31 helical channels, and non-interpenetrating cationic framework with free NO3 – anions balancing the charge of whole framework. Introducing the auxiliary ligand 1,4-BDC2–, compound 2 is constructed by Cd­(II) and mixed ligands, and shows a neutral framework. At the same time, the synergistic effect of 1,4-BDC2– allows compound 2 to have a 3-fold interpenetrated structure with MIL-88 type single-net.

elements.clean_text:
Purity and Thermal Stability of Compounds 1 and 2 

The PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized crystals of compounds 1 and 2 are almost in accordance with their simulated patterns by the Mercury program, indicating the bulk crystal phase sample of compounds 1 and 2 is pure ().

elements.content: Variable-temperature PXRD patterns of compound 1 (a) and compound 2 (b).
elements.clean_text: 3  Variable-temperature PXRD patterns of compound 1 (a) and compound 2 (b).

elements.content: From the TGA (Figure S9, Supporting Information), below 200 °C, compound 1 exhibits a mild weight reduction, which corresponds to the release of free waters. In the range 200–360 °C, the framework of compound 1 starts to collapse due to the loss of free NO3 – anions, The PXRD patterns at different temperatures reveal clearly that the compound 1 can retain its structural integrity up to at least 200 °C. Similarly, the TGA curve of compound 2 displays that the framework loses solvent molecules from 90 to 280 °C. The framework maintains its crystallinity until up to 280 °C. Above 280 °C, a sharp weight loss corresponds to the framework’s collapse. In further, the architectural stability was also confirmed by PXRD patterns at different temperatures which indicate clearly that the compound 2 can retain its structural integrity to at least 280 °C. Comparatively, compound 2 is superior to compound 1 and many MOF materials on thermal stability, and comparable to some classical MOFs, such as PCN-601 and MIL-88. The higher thermal stability of compound 2 may be due to the interpenetrated framework, neutral framework, and highly connected number of [Cd2(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]4+ metal cluster nodes.

elements.content: Luminescent materials have attracted great interest because of their potential applications in photochemistry and also as chemosensors or thermometers. Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were researched. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of free p-tr2Ph ligand, compounds 1 and 2 are illustrated in . The free p-tr2Ph ligand exhibits fluorescence emission at 440 nm, which may be attributed to the intraligand charge transitions (e.g., π*−π or π*-n) under 330 nm light excitation. Meanwhile, complexes 1 and 2 show blue fluorescence with a peak emission at 450 nm for complex 1 (λex = 370 nm) and at 428 nm for complex 2 (λex = 330 nm), which may be assigned to ligand-based luminescence. The emission bands of complexes 1 and 2 are in accordance with that of p-tr2Ph-based luminescent materials reported previously. However, compared to the p-tr2Ph ligand, a red-shift (Δ = 10 nm) in the emission spectra of compound 1 and a slightly blue-shift (Δ = 12 nm) of compound 2 were observed, which may be assigned to the coordination of p-tr2Ph to d10 metal cations and synergistic effects of intraligand and the interligand charge transition as well.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties of Compounds 1 and 2 

Luminescent materials have attracted great interest because of their potential applications in photochemistry and also as chemosensors or thermometers. Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were researched. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of free p-tr2Ph ligand, compounds 1 and 2 are illustrated in . The free p-tr2Ph ligand exhibits fluorescence emission at 440 nm, which may be attributed to the intraligand charge transitions (e.g., π*-π or π*-n) under 330 nm light excitation. Meanwhile, complexes 1 and 2 show blue fluorescence with a peak emission at 450 nm for complex 1 (λex = 370 nm) and at 428 nm for complex 2 (λex = 330 nm), which may be assigned to ligand-based luminescence. The emission bands of complexes 1 and 2 are in accordance with that of p-tr2Ph-based luminescent materials reported previously. However, compared to the p-tr2Ph ligand, a red-shift (Δ = 10 nm) in the emission spectra of compound 1 and a slightly blue-shift (Δ = 12 nm) of compound 2 were observed, which may be assigned to the coordination of p-tr2Ph to d10 metal cations and synergistic effects of intraligand and the interligand charge transition as well.

elements.content: Excitation and emission patterns for p-tr2Ph, compounds 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 4  Excitation and emission patterns for p-tr2Ph, compounds 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Moreover, the enhancement of the emission intensity for complexes 1 and 2 compared to that of free p-tr2Ph ligand may be attributed to the improvement of the ligand configuration rigidity, when the p-tr2Ph ligand bonds to d10 metal ions, leading to a reduction of the nonradiative decay for intraligand excited states.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the enhancement of the emission intensity for complexes 1 and 2 compared to that of free p-tr2Ph ligand may be attributed to the improvement of the ligand configuration rigidity, when the p-tr2Ph ligand bonds to d10 metal ions, leading to a reduction of the nonradiative decay for intraligand excited states.

elements.content: The luminescence intensity of complexes 1 and 2 at different temperatures was investigated for the sake of establishing their potentials as intensity-based luminescence thermometers. The UV light at 370 and 330 nm was selected to excited complex 1 and complex 2, respectively. The emission spectra of solid state complexes 1 and 2 at different temperatures were observed in the range of 80–300 K with 10 K step continuous increments. As illustrated in a, the emission spectra are very similar without any significant changes in the emission center at different temperatures (80–300 K), which indicates complex 1 shows a stable blue emission band. However, the emission intensity at 450 nm for complex 1 gradually decreases as the temperature increases step by step. The emission intensities are 2.24 × 105 at 80 K and 1.27 × 105 at 210 K with 42.8% of attenuation. The enervation of emission intensity may be reasonably ascribed to the increase of thermal activation for nonradiative decay, because the thermodynamic effect will weaken at low temperature. Importantly, the emission intensities at 450 nm (I 450 nm) increases linearly as the temperature (T) decreases (80–210 K) (b), which can be fitted as a function of I 450 nm = a + bT/K (a = 2.71 × 105, b = −6.54 × 102) with good correlation coefficients R 2 = 0.983. Furthermore, the reversibility of the luminescence of compound 1 was investigated thoroughly by monitoring three cycles from 80 to 210 K with good correlation coefficients R 2 = 0.968, 0.957, respectively, which indicates that the change of emission intensity of compound 1 with temperature is reversible. There is no obvious reduction in emission intensity of compound 1 after at least three cycles (b inset), indicating that compound 1 shows potential application as an emission intensity-based luminescent molecular thermometer over a broad range of temperatures from 80 to 210 K.

elements.content: Similarly, when the temperature rises from 80 to 300 K, the emission intensities of compound 2 at 428 nm (I 428 nm) reduce linearly fitting as a function of I 428 nm = a + bT/K (a = 2.87× 105, b = −5.14 × 102) with excellent correlation coefficients R 2 = 0.997 (). Obviously, the compound 2 possesses a superior dependency of fluorescence emission intensity with temperature, and better recyclability. As shown in b, the I 428 nm values are 2.47 × 105 and 1.34 × 105 at 80 and 300 K, respectively, with 45.7% of attenuation. And the emission intensities of compound 2 remain unchanged after three cycles, indicating that the framework of 2 is more robust than that of compound 1, whose emission intensity shows a slight recession with the increasing number of cycles. What is more, the suitable detected temperature of compound 2 falls in a wider range of 80–300 K than compound 1 in 80–210 K. So compound 2 is a more desirable candidate for cryogenic temperature detection. The noteworthy difference between compounds 1 and 2 in a luminescent thermometer may be attributed to their intrinsic structures, such as the 3-fold interpenetration and mixed-ligand synergistic coordination. Further, to the best our knowledge, the cryogenic temperature detector which has such an extremely linear correlation with temperature, reversibility after three cycles, and quite wide range temperature of detection is rare in MOF materials.

elements.content: In summary, two MOFs (1 and 2) were obtained based on the p-conjugated organic lumophore ligand (p-tr2Ph) and d10 transition metal cations by solvothermal methods. Compound 1 is a 3D cationic framework with a left-handed helical channel constructed from a 4-fold right-handed helical chain [Zn­(μ2-tr)2­(μ2-NO3)] n . Compound 2 is a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral architecture with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. Compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit blue fluorescence. Notably, the intensity-based luminescent thermometer measurements indicate that compound 2 is more linear with temperature, has finer reversibility within three cycles, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1, indicating that compound 2 is a more desirable cryogenic temperature detector.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two MOFs (1 and 2) were obtained based on the p-conjugated organic lumophore ligand (p-tr2Ph) and d10 transition metal cations by solvothermal methods. Compound 1 is a 3D cationic framework with a left-handed helical channel constructed from a 4-fold right-handed helical chain [Zn(μ2-tr)2(μ2-NO3)] n . Compound 2 is a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D neutral architecture with 1D distorted hexagonal channels in each MIL-88 type single-net. Compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit blue fluorescence. Notably, the intensity-based luminescent thermometer measurements indicate that compound 2 is more linear with temperature, has finer reversibility within three cycles, and a wider temperature range than those of compound 1, indicating that compound 2 is a more desirable cryogenic temperature detector.

cln_elements.content:
All the chemicals commercial available were used directly. The p-tr2Ph was prepared by the literature method.

Synthesis of [Zn­(μ<sub>4</sub>-<italic>p</italic>-tr<sub>2</sub>Ph)­(μ<sub>2</sub>-NO<sub>3</sub>)]·NO<sub>3</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The mixture of p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60.2 mg), 1 mL of DMF, and 5 mL of CH3CN solvents was added to a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred for about 1 h, the resulting mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and was kept at 85 °C for 5 days. After being naturally cooled to ambient temperature, the colorless columnar crystals of 1 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 86% (based on p-tr2Ph). CdSO4 (42.4 mg), p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), and 1,4-H2BDC (17.6 mg), 1 mL of DMF, 3 mL of CH3CN, and 2 mL of H2O were added into a 20 mL reactor vial. After being stirred at for about 1 h, the mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and then was kept at 100 °C for 5 days. This synthetic method is different from that in the literature and has the advantage of high yields.

Materials and Synthesis Methods

All the chemicals commercial available were used directly. The p-tr2Ph was prepared by the literature method.

The mixture of p-tr2Ph (12.6 mg), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60.2 mg), 1 mL of DMF, and 5 mL of CH3CN solvents was added to a 20 mL reactor vial. After being naturally cooled to ambient temperature, the colorless columnar crystals of 1 were isolated after filtration. Yield: 86% (based on p-tr2Ph). Synthesis of {[Cd2(μ4-1,4-BDC)2(μ4-p-tr2Ph)(μ2-DMF)(H2O)2]}⋅2H2O (2)

After being stirred at for about 1 h, the mixture was sealed in the reactor vial and then was kept at 100 °C for 5 days. cln_elements.content:
In the whole structure, the free NO3 – anions are suspended in the channels for neutralization of the cationic framework, which can be confirmed by element analysis and valence calculation. PLATON calculation shows compound 1 has 50.7% potential guest-accessible volumes (1679.0 Å3) without free NO3 – anions (Figure S3, Supporting Information). From the topological viewpoint, compound 1 exhibits a 3D (4, 6)-network topology. The μ4-p-tr2Ph ligands can be viewed as the 4-connected nodes, and the six-coordinated Zn­(II) cations can be served as 6-connected nodes (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The Schlafli symbol is {32.63.7}­{34.42.63.74.82}, determined by the TOPOS4 program.

From the TGA (Figure S9, Supporting Information), below 200 °C, compound 1 exhibits a mild weight reduction, which corresponds to the release of free waters. In the range 200–360 °C, the framework of compound 1 starts to collapse due to the loss of free NO3 – anions, The PXRD patterns at different temperatures reveal clearly that the compound 1 can retain its structural integrity up to at least 200 °C. Similarly, the TGA curve of compound 2 displays that the framework loses solvent molecules from 90 to 280 °C. The framework maintains its crystallinity until up to 280 °C. Above 280 °C, a sharp weight loss corresponds to the framework’s collapse. In further, the architectural stability was also confirmed by PXRD patterns at different temperatures which indicate clearly that the compound 2 can retain its structural integrity to at least 280 °C. Comparatively, compound 2 is superior to compound 1 and many MOF materials on thermal stability, and comparable to some classical MOFs, such as PCN-601 and MIL-88. The higher thermal stability of compound 2 may be due to the interpenetrated framework, neutral framework, and highly connected number of [Cd2(μ2-DMF)­(H2O)2]4+ metal cluster nodes.

Photoluminescence Properties of Compounds <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

Luminescent materials have attracted great interest because of their potential applications in photochemistry and also as chemosensors or thermometers. Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were researched. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of free p-tr2Ph ligand, compounds 1 and 2 are illustrated in . The free p-tr2Ph ligand exhibits fluorescence emission at 440 nm, which may be attributed to the intraligand charge transitions (e.g., π*−π or π*-n) under 330 nm light excitation. Meanwhile, complexes 1 and 2 show blue fluorescence with a peak emission at 450 nm for complex 1 (λex = 370 nm) and at 428 nm for complex 2 (λex = 330 nm), which may be assigned to ligand-based luminescence. The emission bands of complexes 1 and 2 are in accordance with that of p-tr2Ph-based luminescent materials reported previously. However, compared to the p-tr2Ph ligand, a red-shift (Δ = 10 nm) in the emission spectra of compound 1 and a slightly blue-shift (Δ = 12 nm) of compound 2 were observed, which may be assigned to the coordination of p-tr2Ph to d10 metal cations and synergistic effects of intraligand and the interligand charge transition as well.

Two d10 Metal–Organic Frameworks as Low-Temperature Luminescent
